column2: ENGLISH
Haskalah

After the Event, the many progressive Jewish movements that began after the Haskalah, or Jewish Enlightement, began to organize together to insure their survival throughout the centuries. While opinions differ between the movements on Jewish Law, all permit women to be ordained as rabbis and allow marriage between same-sex couples. The Jews of the Haskalah maintain that individual Jews should work towards restoring the pre-Event world through good works and philanthropy. This principle is known as "Tikkun Olam"-- literally, "repair of the world".
§Y*§! Jewish counties are hard to convert. \n§Y*§! Absolute Cognatic succession is allowed for all Reform rulers. \n§Y*§! Homosexual Haskalah rulers are allowed to marry other homosexual characters.
Ma'aravi

The Ma'aravi are a Jewish movement popular in the Empire of California, rejected by other for their beliefs that Muhammed, Buddha, Elton, Jesus and others were "Prophets of the other nations" who also recieved divine wisdom that they can learn from.

§Y*§! Jewish counties are hard to convert. 
§Y*§! Absolute Cognatic succession is allowed for all Ma'aravi rulers. 
§Y*§! Homosexual Reform rulers are allowed to marry other homosexual characters. 
§Y*§! Bureaucratic Government is Enabled
Muscular

Following the event, and the rise of religious persecution and Anti-Semitism, a new group re-emerged out of the Jewish communities - the Maccabis. This group calls for forceful takeover of land for Jewish communities, and is looked down upon by most Haskalah communities.

§Y*§! Jewish counties are hard to convert. 
§Y*§! Absolute Cognatic succession is allowed for all Muscular rulers. 
§Y*§! Homosexual Reform rulers are allowed to marry other homosexual characters. 
§Y*§! Holy Wars are allowed
Litvak

Litvaks stress highly intellectual Talmud study through yeshivas. They descend from earlier opponents to the Chassidic movent known as the Misnagdim, who were centered around the area of Greater Lithuania.
Breslover

Breslover Chassids follow the teachings of Rebbe Nachman of Breslov, who stressed building a personal connection with God and advocated for Kiruv (outreach to non-Haredi Jews). He left no successor and encouraged his followers to remain decentralized.
Chassid
The Chassidic movement developed in the 1800s beginning with the Baal Shem Tov. Chassids follow one of many courts, each run by a Rebbe of a given dynasty.
Reform
Reform Jews regard Halakha (Jewish religious law) as non-binding, instead insisting that the individual Jew is autonomous.
Conservative
Conservative Jews believe that Halakha (Jewish religious law) is binding, but that earlier decisions of Rabbis may be overturned and updated as the times require.
Renewal
The Renewal movement incorporates Chassidic thought and a popularized approach to kabbalah with the Reform positions on Halakha, Tikkun Olam and Egalitarianism.
Change Haredi Movement
I can change the Haredi movement that I belong to
Change your Haredi movement
As a Jewish  adult, I can make my own decision for which movement I want to dedicate myself to:
I will follow the teachings of the Vilna Gaon and the Litvaks
Gain the Litvak trait
I will follow the teachings of the Baal Shem Tov and the Chassidim
Gain the Chassid trait
I will follow the teachings of Nachman of Breslov and the Breslover Chassidim
Gain the Breslov trait
Change Haskalah Movement
I can change the movement within Haskalah Judaism that I belong to
Changes your Haskalah movement
As a Jewish  adult, I can make my own decision for which movement I want to dedicate myself to:
The Conservative movement appeals to me most
Gain the Conservative trait
The Reform movement is the best option for me.
Gain the Reform trait
I believe that the Jewish Renewal is where I belong
Gain the Renewal trait

The Bedikat Hametz has begun in your palace to prepare for the Passover Seder. The members of your household have begun searching for leftover crumbs of leavened bread with a feather, a candle, and a wooden spoon, gathering each crumb so that the palace will be clean and ready for the day Passover arrives.
Let the children and servants do this! It is not fit for a [Root.GetTitle]!
To make the palace clean for Passover is my duty as well. I will join.
Yetzer Ha'Ra

The Seder is winding down, with all your guests looking tired and satisfied. One of your guest has clearly had one too many cups of wine, and insists you join him for the "fifth cup" of Slivovitz, a strong plum brandy he brought from his cellar
Of course my friend!
I'm sorry but I must get to sleep.
Welcoming Host
Sold Chametz

The Passover meal has ended, but the Seder is no over yet. You pour a cup of wine for the prophet Elijah and open the door to welcome him when you see an old beggar standing outside, hoping for leftovers from the kitchen.
Come in and sit with us, let all who are hungry come eat at our Seder Table!
Take some leftovers from the kitchen and leave.
[From.GetTitleName] kept feasting with you after the seder has ended, with more wine constantly being poured.
Sure!
Rabbi
Rabbis
Anti-Defamation Legion
